anchor.surface_text: On Shanker Lals death disputes arose between Shanker Lals fathers brothers son Brijlal  the plaintiffs grandfather  and the defendants grandmother Mst. Mohan Dei.

facts.text: Brijlal claimed entire estate by survivorship alleging jointness with Shanker Lal.

anchor.surface_text: Brijlal claimed the entire estate by survivorship, his allegation being that Shanker Lal dies in a state of jointness with him and that all the properties were joint family properties.

facts.text: Dispute referred to arbitration and award delivered on 21-12-1884.

anchor.surface_text: This dispute was referred to arbitration and an award was delivered. Under the Mst. Mohan Dei was given the suit properties as absolute owner and the rest of the estate then in dispute was given to Brijlal.

facts.text: Award gave Mst. Mohan Dei suit properties as absolute owner.

anchor.surface_text: A division was effected accordingly and ever since, that is to say from 21-12-1884, the date of the award, down to 26-3-1941, the date of the suit,

facts.text: Plaintiffs lost in first court, won in High Court.

facts.text: Defendants appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff lost in the first Court but won in the High Court. The defendants appeal.

issues.text: What was the nature of the estate conferred on Mst. Mohan Dei by the arbitration award - absolute or limited?

anchor.surface_text: The first question is about the nature of the award. The defendants say that it gave Mst. Mohan Dei an absolute estate. The plaintiff deny this and say she obtained only a limited estate.

issues.text: Did the arbitrator travel beyond the terms of the reference by awarding Mst. Mohan Dei an absolute interest?

anchor.surface_text: The award was attacked on other grounds also. It was urged, among other things, that the arbitrator had travelled beyond the terms of his reference in awarding Mst Mohan Dei an absolute interest.

issues.text: If Brijlal was bound by the award, was his son Kishan Lal bound despite having an independent title as reversioner?

anchor.surface_text: It was also urged that even if Brijlal was bound his son Kishan Lal, who did number claim through him but who had an independent title as reversioner to Shanker Lal, would number be bound, and it was companytended that if Kishan Lal was number bound the plaintiffs would number be either.

holdings.text: The award gave Mst. Mohan Dei an absolute estate in the suit properties.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the defendants are rights. The question at issue a simple one of companystruction. The award is Ex. A-1. The operative portion runs thus Having regard to the specifications give above, Brij Lal, first party, and Musammat Mohan Devi,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Operative portion unambiguously uses 'malik mustaqil' meaning permanent owner; earlier passages do not qualify; supported by precedents like Ram Gopal and Bishunath Prasad.

holdings.text: Even if the award be invalid, the plaintiffs' claim is completely answered by the plea of estoppel.

anchor.surface_text: But we need number examine these points because we do number need to proceed on the binding nature of the award. Even if the award be invalid we are of the opinion that the plaintiffs claims is companypletely answered by the plea of estoppel.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Estoppel arises independently of award's validity; three elements satisfied by conduct of parties.

holdings.text: Brijlal was estopped from denying Mst. Mohan Dei's absolute estate.

anchor.surface_text: In any event, we are clear that that created an estoppel as against Brijlal. In our opinion, the present case is very similar to the one which their Lordship of the Privy Council decided in Kanhai Lal v. Brij Lal   1919  45 I.A. 118 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Brijlal represented acceptance of award giving absolute estate, inducing Mst. Mohan Dei to detriment; similar to Kanhai Lal v. Brij Lal.

holdings.text: There was an independent estoppel against Kishan Lal.

anchor.surface_text: But apart from this, there was also an independent estoppel in Kishan Lal. We have said, he had numberright of the this part to this part of the estate when his father died apart from the award.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Kishan Lal took possession under award, knew of it, no objection to mutations or gift, inaction for 40 years induced continued dealing as absolute owner.

holdings.text: The estoppel against Kishan Lal continued after he became reversioner upon opening of reversion.

anchor.surface_text: We have numberdoubt that the time Kishan Lal was also estopped fro the reason given above. Had he questioned the award and reopened the dispute Mst. Mohan Dei would at once have used and would then for forty years have obtained the benefit

holdings.reasoning_summary: Estoppel binds consenting reversioner post-opening per Kanhai Lal and Ramgouda; distinguished Rangasami and Binda Kuer as full benefit taken under award with no independent title portion.

holdings.text: Plaintiffs who claim through Kishan Lal are also estopped.

anchor.surface_text: It was companycede that if the estoppel against Kishan Lal endured after October 1929, then the plaintiff who claim through Kishan Lal, would also be estopped. The appeal succeeds.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Estoppel binds successors claiming through estopped party.

holdings.text: The passages relied on do not qualify the operative portion of the award.
